prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for thinking my girlfriend is using sex as a power play?
So I earlier today I was trying to make plans with my girlfriend for later tonight. She asked me if we could not have sex tonight since we do it pretty much every time we hang out and she just wants so time to chill and do other things. I told her no problem as I know we do it often so it doesn't really make a difference. We continue the conversation trying to figure out exactly what we want to do on this boring Friday night.

&#x200B;

We decided what we would make for dinner (I was gonna cook some pasta) and start trying to figure out how to spend the evening. I suggest she bring over one of her game systems and we could just hang out and play some video games. (I have 2 TVs so we would be able to do more than one game at a time) She tells me she wants to do something together instead of playing video games next to each other. I told her I really wanted to play some video games since I haven't be able to in a while (Midterms) and I finally have a chance to. At the end of the day it doesn't really matter to me as long as I get to spend time with her. 

&#x200B;

She then tells me that we can have sex tonight if I don't play any video games. Obviously I told her of course I choose that option. I said that it is fine I can just play before she comes over (There is like a 2 hour gap in between when I get home and when she was planning to come over) She then clarifies and says that in order for us to have sex tonight, I can't play at all today. I try clarifying as well by telling her that if would be in the time before i see her and not during. She says its fine we don't need to have sex and we can do something else instead.

&#x200B;

So now I get pretty upset and I tell her WTF why is she trying to hold sex over my head. I reason that it makes literally no difference if I play games before we hang out. I agreed not to play anything DURING our evening but there is absolutely no reason I should be prohibited to enjoy myself before we hang out. I told her that its pretty fucked up to use sex as a power play just to see if she can get me to bend over for her.

&#x200B;

She says that she doesn't see it that way and that it was just an offer. She says I have every right to decline and we would just go back to the original plan of not messing around tonight. My reasoning is that an offer would have a benefited outcome on both sides. (For example no video games while we hang out = sex) but this situation has no benefit for her by me not playing games before we hang out. I said that this makes it a power play and I am not okay with that.

&#x200B;

She doesn't see this and is just telling me it is a difference of opinion. Now we aren't speaking and as of now NOTHING is happening tonight at all. So AITA here? Am I missing something and looking at this from the wrong perspective?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is about the girlfriend not wanting to have sex and instead suggesting other activities, but then the author is upset when she offers to have sex if he gives up his gaming time. 

First, the author says he agreed to not play during their evening together but wanted to play before she arrives. The girlfriend insists he can't play at all that day to have sex. The author feels it's a power play because he thinks it's unreasonable to give up gaming before they meet. He calls it holding sex over his head. She says it's just an offer and there's a difference in opinions.

Hmm. The key points here are about control and compromise. The author is upset because he feels the offer is manipulative. He's not okay with giving up his gaming time just to have sex, which he sees as her using sex as leverage. On the other hand, the girlfriend might be trying to balance their time together, maybe feeling that too much sex is dominating their time, and wants more variety. 

But wait, the author agreed to not play during their evening but wanted to play before. The girlfriend's condition is that he can't play at all that day. The author sees this as a power play because he's giving up something (his game time) for her to agree to have sex. That does sound like using sex as a bargaining chip, which could be manipulative. However, she frames it as an offer, not a demand. 

But maybe the problem is that the author is feeling pressured to give up his own time for her condition. If she's using the offer of sex as a way to get him to comply with her terms, that's a power imbalance. On the flip side, if the author is also using the threat of not spending time together to get his way, that's also a power play. 

The author's main argument is that the offer isn't mutual—she's getting something (him not playing games) without giving him anything in return except a conditional sex. That does seem like an unequal exchange. However, the girlfriend might see it as a fair trade for that night's activity. 

The question is whether the author is wrong for calling it a power play. If the girlfriend genuinely saw it as an offer and not manipulation, and the author is interpreting it as such, maybe there's a communication issue. But if the author is right that it's a power play, then he's justified in his feelings. 

Alternatively, maybe the author is overreacting. If the girlfriend is trying to set boundaries for her own comfort, and the author is being rigid about his own needs, both could have some responsibility. The author might be in the wrong if he's dismissing her boundaries. But if she's using sex to control the situation, he's right to push back.

I think the answer depends on whether the condition is manipulative or a legitimate boundary. If the girlfriend is trying to balance their time and the author is being unreasonable, maybe he's in the wrong. But if she's using sex as a tool to control, he's justified. Since the user thinks the author is wrong, but the analysis is mixed, it's a close call. However, the girlfriend's offer could be seen as her trying to set a boundary, and the author is not respecting it by calling it a power play. So maybe the answer is A.
